text: Angle on: the plastic exterior of a screen-less televisio
Through it we see children running in circles on a footba pitch.
Angle on the boy balancing it on his head, AGU (10), a wa smile and clever eyes. Next to him, DIKE, his littler bes friend.
Which ones having talent?
That one...not that one.
Agu passes a line of YOUNG MEN lying on wheel barrows whi carrying the TV. Dike and their YOUNG RECRUITS, the kids were scouting on the football pitch, follow suit.
Agu and Dike drop the TV down on a stool in front of the VILLAGE CONSTABLE, charming it up.
Agu, what am I supposed to be doing with this?
Watching TV, Massah.
It is not having a screen.
It is imagination TV.
Agu has the YOUNG RECRUITS perform, framed in the empty s of the demolished television. The Constable is unimpresse
It is garbage. Go, get out of here.
Agu disappointed but not discouraged, looks at the PEACE OBSERVERS with optimism.
Agu stands in front of white helmeted NIGERIAN troops. Th 2ND LIEUTENANT humors him.
It doesn't have any channels.
Agu turns the knob swiftly.
It is having 12, and one more, that is the imagination channel.
He addresses his YOUNG RECRUITS to PERFORM again. The 2nd Lieutenant is amused.
And how much for this treasure?
3000. And you are giving us some of your foods.
2nd Lieutenant motions to his CORPORAL to get something o of the carrier. The corporal comes back with several PLAS CONTAINERS OF RICE AND SAUCE.
Take these.
Agu reviews the food. 2nd Lieutenant pulls out a pack of from his side pocket to sweeten the deal. Agu snatches up takings, giving some cash to Dike and his recruits.
Agu walks home with Dike, arguing playfully, when a cheap puttering Chinese motorcycle pulls up with BIG BROTHER (1 and a FRIEND.
What are you two girls plotting?
Agu looks up.
Big Brother.
Come, I have job for you.
Agu hangs from a tree. Dike hangs from another branch as each take turns sawing a larger branch.
Big Brother directs them from below.
Big Brother. He is always having ideas.
They cut the large tree limb and let it crash across the street just as a BUSH TAXI comes. They charge it a "tax".

As Agu counts the change, an OLD WITCH WOMAN arrives from bush. From everyone's reaction to her we can see she is t crazy of the village. All the BOYS watch her warily. The WOMAN focuses in on Agu in particular.
Enh!   You are not greeting me?
The old woman holds out a handful of groundnuts, dirty an greasy in her palms.
Witch woman. Nobody is talking to her because every person is fearing her.
The Old Woman talks while rearranging her ground nuts in palm.
These young person not behaving well anymore, just acting like animal. But it is okay.
Trouble go follow you.
No trouble go follow me. I am a good boy.
A Bush Taxi zooms PAST, barely missing the old woman.
Trouble go touch you old woman if you stay standing in the middle of the road.
I am knowing you, boy. I am knowing your family. And trouble go follow all of you. Thieves! Throw an old woman like me from her land! Devil go bless your family!
Another bush taxi zooms by as she goes on her way RANTING herself.
I have a good family.

Agu's FATHER (30's) teaches a primary school class about African fauna. Agu can barely stay awake as he looks out window. Father snaps his fingers in his face, asking "Whe do the lions live, Agu?" Agu responds, "In the zoo."
My Father was   a teacher. But since war is making   it so we have no more school, he is   keeping busy.
FATHER, who is Agu's father, directs the building of a makeshift INTERNALLY DISPLACED PERSON (IDP) camp along wi the PARAMOUNT CHIEF.
He and the Paramount Chief cut some of our land so that all of the refugees can be having a place to be staying. Mother is saying he is always doing good things.
Agu lays on his MOTHER's (30's) back as he reads out loud from a nature magazine. Father observes them while smokin his pipe. Agu looks up at his father happily, comfortable safe.
Mother. Before she was having children she was also being a teacher, but she is saying raising childrens is too too much work.
Agu sits behind his MOTHER preparing dinner while humming SONG. She QUIZZES Agu on the ingredients of the meal she making.
He enjoys watching her work, his BABY BROTHER swaddled on back as she SINGS.
LITTLE SISTER sits next to him, mimicking him.
My mother is always working hard for us and so I am thanking her by working hard too.
On the road home, Agu, comfortably sitting between his Bi Brother and a friend, notices 16 REFUGEES walking TOWARDS village, their meager items placed on their head.
For Agu, they are impossibly fascinating.
Big Brother takes a bath in an outdoor shower surrounded thatch. He is covered in suds when he feels Agu peeing a spray on him. He clears his face in the pee and immediate tears after Agu.
Big Brother, he is more concerned with his muscles, and his skin. Sometimes I add to his products.

Big Brother has captured Agu and is rolling him up in a t carpet that makes it impossible for him to use his arms t escape. He looks like a tampon with a head as Big Brother props him up against the wall.
Big Brother is also concerned with sleeping.
Big Brother is talking about sleeping with a girl in the village as he dances to music from a tape deck.
I am not liking his music, and I am not like his dancing, and if he is playing it loud loud I do not know how this girl will be sleeping.
Fuming, Agu looks like he is about to cry as he yells at brother to be let go.
Agu sits uncomfortably on one of the church benches among hundreds of people listening to a PASTOR with his SUPPORT STAFF with MUSICIANS behind them.
I am going to church every Sunday with my family.
He looks up, distracted, at the spinning CEILING FANS. Mo pinches his leg, motioning for him to pay attention.
Big Brother is making eyes with a TEENAGE GIRL from acros the aisle. She returns his affection coyly.
Agu looks at Father who pretends like he is dozing to entertain Agu.
Father is saying that Pastor is thinking he can be talking so much because he is having his Reverend Doctorate -- that is making him doctor of "talking."
On another pew, Dike sits with a well dressed family. The raise their chins in salutation as everyone stands to sin
The PARISHIONERS spill out of the church clapping and sin in a parade of music and dance. The church brass and percussion band BLASTING A CELEBRATORY TUNE.
God is liking    music more than just talking so if    we are singing and dancing, then    He is listening to us well well.
FATHER snatches the Tape Player from the shelf, hitting t machine to make it stop.
What is wrong with you? You know you cannot waste batteries on such nonsense!
Agu and Big Brother can't help laughing as Father slaps t laugh out of Big Brother from the back of his head.
And you? What are you doing? (to Big Brother) Unroll him.
Big Brother snaps the carpet, spinning Agu.
Agu. What are these?!
Father holds up several the plastic containers of food.
Well?
I?   I. I. I. what?
I got them from the Nigerians.
We do not need handouts. We are not beggars on the street. We are not refugees. I work for this family and I provide for this family.
But I earned-
You will return them.
Yes, Father.
Father looks at Agu a beat longer to ensure Agu understan then he tenders a forced smile to release the tension.
Good dancing.
Go on, help Mother.
Agu's Sister sweeps the grounds between the kitchen hut a the main house with a small wad of reeds fashioned into a broom. Agu grates a long reedy root into a bowl.
Inside the house, Agu spies FATHER resting on a chair whi listening to the RADIO, a BBC-like AFRICAN CORRESPONDENT reporting...

It would seem things are changing quickly within the interim government. As of this morning, the NRC junta moved to abolish all political parties, further consolidating their control of the government in the wake of the recent military coup...
Agu's GRANDFATHER sits on a bench. His eyes are open, sta into the courtyard, but he does not appear to be awake, f buzzing around his milky eyes.
Agu walks in front of him, bending closer to look at him, makes funny poses, does "the robot." Grandfather does not react.
Lieutenant General Sangania, commander-in-chief of the armed forces responsible for the junta, stated in a recent press conference that it was his intention to rid the southern regions of the PLF...

Agu leans in closer to his Grandfather, seeing that his father is not paying attention, he uses the long reed and tickles Grandfather's nostrils. His nose twitches but he not stop Agu. Agu laughs to himself.
He also condemned the Native Defence Force militias, who he said presented a threat to the very fabric of national security...
Seeing Agu, FATHER turns off the radio.
Agu, realizing he is caught, turns towards Father but hol the straw behind his back.
Expecting to be yelled at, Agu's father says...
It's okay Agu, do not be worrying. We are in a safe place, we are in
"-Buffer zone". That is why so many refugee are coming here small small. Many people are suffering but we are not, here we are safe.
Agu walks back to the kitchen. In the background, we hear BBC Correspondent back ON again.
Agu and Big Brother fill up water for the evening's cooki and dishes. Big Brother's arms work hard to pump the wate He looks at Agu, contemplating.
When I was your age, if I was doing the same things you are doing, Father would beat me. You are lucky this war is happening.
I am not lucky. It is just because everyone is liking me.
Just then some MEN passing by yell out, "Hello Agu!" Big Brother is ignored. Agu notices the teenage girl Big Brot likes passing by, so does he, pumping harder.
As she disappears down the bend, he motions to his arms.
When she is seeing these, her knees must be wobbling with hunger.
Agu snorts with laughter now.
As if the dialogue continues, Agu and Big Brother carry w on their heads.
And you will see, I will be like this with all the girls in town.
He kisses the air on each side of him several times, as i were surrounded by women that wanted a peck on the lips f him.
Agu, his Big Brother, his Father, his Mother, and his bab sister sit on the floor of the house around a large dinne plate of rice with cassava.
Agu feeds his Grandfather, who chews slowly, but again se unaffected by his surroundings. When he can, Agu stuffs h face with food to catch up to everyone else.
We are seeing that witch woman on the road today. She is saying we are thieves. Why is she saying that?

She is not right in her head. God has taken away her ration. The land we are letting the refugees use has been in our family since before your Grandfather, we gave her a place in the camp but she refused.
Agu watches his father eat, slowly, tasting and appreciat every bite, smiling at Mother. Agu realizes his own way o eating is much more voracious and hasty. He mimics his fa the next bite.
So she's crazy?
Agu burps involuntarily.
Father looks up from his meal. Mother sighs as Big Brothe joins with a burp, too.
Agu laughs, as Father joins in with his own long and bellowing BURRRRRP. Agu is in tears laughing.
They quiet down again, but suddenly Sister FARTS. They al are hysterical on the floor.
Eventually the laughter subsides and Father notices somet beyond Agu.
Enh?   What is that?
Agu looks over his shoulder.
Enh?
Father gets up and walks across the room.
What is this?
Big Brother notices, too, and his eyes lead us to...
INSERT: on a TV WITHOUT its case. The tube and the knobs dangling by its side. It is the TV that Agu sold.
Father lunges after Agu. FREEZE FRAME again.
Agu sleeps on the front porch, afraid to go inside.
I am a good boy. But sometimes I am sleeping outside so I am not having to go inside and be getting a beating.
The lights go out on the porch. Agu looks out over the to as all lights go out.
Mother lights candles and lamps and steps out over him to what is going on in town.

Father walks over with his radio, shaking it for a better signal. She looks to him for an answer as a RADIO BROADCA plays the voice of the LIEUTENANT GENERAL addressing the and requesting they lay down their weapons in return for amnesty within 24 hours.
Why so fearful? Doesn't the light go out all the time? It will come back.
Mother holds onto Father. Agu watches them from the doorw She turns towards him, adjusting her display of fear.
Go on Agu, go to bed.
No beating?
Father brings Mother in close, Agu waits for an answer.
Get up! Get up, now!    We are going to church!
Father shakes Agu awake. Agu, still groggy, hides his fac from the light.
But it is not Sunday.
Agu sees his Father's stress. So does Big Brother.
Agu and his family watch as a long convoy of NRC Junta Ar trucks enter their town.
It is saying in the Bible that God is only helping those who are helping themselves.
Agu and family are pressed against the wall, everyone dri with sweat.
Agu, between the towering adults, looks up at the fans bu they are not turning.
Isn't God protecting the Israelites when they are having to leave their own home?
Big Brother sees Agu struggling below and picks him up an puts him on his shoulders so he can see. Agu whispers to brother...
Where is Dike?

Agu scans the room for Dike and his family, but cannot se them. The Pastor speaks from a podium while an ECOMOD CAPTAIN, LOCAL IMAM, PARAMOUNT CHIEF holding his golden talisman, a LINGUIST, ASSISTANT PASTOR, VILLAGE ELDERS, O FEMALE REPRESENTATIVE sit behind him.
Agu smiles to himself, the Pastor looks desperate to him.
We cannot allow ourselves to face voluntary self-destruction. May God bless us all!
Reverend Doctorate.

Agu looks down at his Father to share his observation, bu his father has a look that Agu has never seen before: fea The entire room is gripped with it as they murmur their concerns and beliefs to their neighbors.
What about our homes, property we leave behind? Our crops? Who will protect them?
The crowd goes silent as the PARAMOUNT CHIEF leans forwar
Linguist.
The Linguist joins him at his side, leaning over to liste The crowd leans in, knowing that the Linguist will only filter.
I am listening to the Pastor and to the Imam, and the representative for the women, and what they have to say is wise, but not all of it. It is right that we must be helping ourselves.
The NRC Junta telling us to be running away is not acceptable. Our forefathers have lived on this land for centuries. It is our duty to preserve it for our children.
The crowd adjusts and shifts nervously.

Now that the NRC has broken its promise and entered the buffer zone, we should be accepting ECOMOD help and be sending women and the small small children to safer areas. But we who call ourselves men must stay.
Some of the crowd reacts in favor of the Chief while many more MOAN in fear, drowning out the Linguist's call...
(shouting over the crowd) The Section Chiefs and their deputies should be assembling after this to discuss protection of this village. We all must do our part.
FAMILIES ERUPT in protest. The crowd DIVIDES and breaks i arguments again.
How can the world be doing      We must all be leaving, t nothing if we have rebels so    is the only way. so close?!
Rebels over here, Army over     What about the refugees? there, it is so so bad. We      people must be helped fir will be squashed in the middle!
The refugees are our problem, they are our guests.
Insults are slung from across one side of the room to another, but the Chief is done and parts the crowd on his out.
Father, I am not seeing Dike.
Mother looks at Father. Pleadingly.
It is my responsibility...
Father, where is Dike?
Dike and his family are gone!     They fled.
Agu and Big Brother watch Father push his way through the crowd towards the Paramount Chief and Elders, disappearin with other Section Chiefs.
Agu and Big Brother listen through a wall as his mother a father argue. They play with flashlights over a game of draughts.
He cannot be moved, he is an old man. And I won't force-
Sometimes I am thinking that you are having no sense at all.
What is so irrational about staying with your sister in the Capital, I will be coming to meet you once I am knowing everything is safe here. I cannot just be abandoning my responsibilities.
But then you are abandoning us.
Father throws his arms up in frustration.
Just remove that thought from you head. What are we just supposed to be doing, then? Enh? Just running into the bush and living like rats?
No, you are not understanding anything.
Do you want me to be a refugee in my own country, with three children in my arms and no husband? We are one family, we must be staying as one family.
I am not asking you. I am telling you woman.
Father knows he deeply wounded Mother, but he also knows will not argue further, even at the cost of their intimac

ECOMOD TROOPS stand next to a JEEP, TWO TROOP CARRIERS, A SEVERAL CIVILIAN LORIES in the market. A CONVOY of TRUCKS filled with stuff and people piled on top muscles out of town, leaving them in a black cloud of exhaust.
The market is packed with men trying to pack their women children into bush taxis, trucks, dump trunks and flat be any vehicle that will help them evacuate.
Father pulls his family towards one of the last cars to b loaded. The DRIVER, a flat and sweaty face with froth in corners of his mouth, cuts him off-
Come back tomorrow.
I am the Section Chief and this is my family, there must be space.
No space.
Just one woman and these small small children.
The driver looks at Agu's mother, little brother strapped her back, and sister, and then down at Agu.
And the little boy?
I am not a "little" boy.
The driver, amused, reveals black teeth.
Him, too.

The Driver scratches his head doing basic spatial math: t are at least NINE people piled into the front and back se of the station wagon. The trunk is filled with luggage as well as a pile on the roof towering at least ten-feet hig
And where are you thinking this woman and child will be fitting.
I am thinking this women and children are more valuable than all this luggage you have piled in back.
He points to the front.
They can be sitting with you in the front.
The driver laughs off the suggestion.
With the boy-
-The driver raises his finger to shush him...
We will find another way.
No!
With the boy.
No bargaining. Or are you wanting your woman to be walking through the bush to the capital?
Mother looks prideful.
I would rather be walking then leaving my child.
I am not leaving him.
Please. How much to fit the boy?
No boy.
TWO FAMILIES, seeing an opportunity, start OFFERING MONEY the driver to take the Mother's space. Without recourse, Father starts pushing her towards the car.
No. No we cannot!
Father is picking up Little Sister to place her inside.
No, I cannot!
(whispering, consoling) Do not scare them. You are strong. You will be okay. Take care of them and I will take care of our boys. Now get in, there is no choice.
Father pays the Driver as Mother kneels down to Agu, unab to speak, on the verge of breaking down...
Remember to be praying praying to God all the time and not to be worrying, we will be seeing each other soon.
She hugs and kisses him, grabs his hands, before turning away.
She slides into the front seat, the gearshift situated between her legs, Sister and Little Brother on her lap. T more people between her and the passenger door. All are h uncomfortable, and scared.
Mother!
She cannot bear to be looking at Agu, Big Brother or Fath instead, she looks a the faces around her, and then forwa
Father holds Agu by both shoulders in front of him. Agu begins to cry. He cannot see Mother. He tries to move but Father holds him back.
You are with the men now, Agu. Be strong, wave goodbye.
Big Brother is holding back tears as well, struggling jus hard to be strong.
The engine rumbles to a start spewing black smoke onto Ag and what's left of his family.
As the car pulls away, Agu cannot help himself, he breaks away and runs after the car, crying after his mother.
Mama!
Agu's brother grabs his hand and holds him back.
Let's go home.
Father looks at them tenderly. The square, filled with th sounds of straining engines and crying families.
And this is how it is starting.
The last light of day.
Agu, Big Brother, his Father and Grandfather sit around a meager plate of rice and sauce.
They eat quietly. Agu doesn't like the taste of his fathe cooking.

If I am closing my eye, I am seeing the rainy season and how in my village, they are saying it is always bringing change too fast. You can be finding that the whole world is washing away beneath your feets.
Father feeds Grandfather, the activity helping keep his thoughts in order.

Outside, THUNDER rolls, or   something that sounds like i Father is acutely aware of   it, as if it could be artill Agu doesn't seem to notice   as the camera moves away fro family and out towards the   wet countryside.

You can be walking on road and finding that you are swimming in river. You can be starting day all dry and warm and then be finishing with your clothes like another skin on your body. Nothing is ever for sure and everything is always changing.
The SOUNDS OF BATTLE replace thunder. More coarse, pierci booms than thunder. Panting breath. Pattering feet.
Agu runs with his Father, Big Brother, and Grandfather do the middle of town.
Just behind them a contingent of 20 PLF REBELS descend on foot. Bullets zip by.
Agu and his family find a SMALL GROUP of civilians waitin the ground, pinned down by gunfire. Some of the MEN from Church with clubs and machetes.
Father nods to them, points in one direction. They shake their heads. He points in the other direction. They shake their heads no again.
They ALL slip between the stairs of the same building, assessing their situation. Rebels spread out on the hill overlooking the town.

There is no where to go. Father looks at his children, knowing it was a mistake not to get them out of town. Beckoned by a village man, the family runs across the roa Grandfather on Big Brother's back, into a building where other villagers are hiding.

Water leaks from the ceiling onto the group of TEN MEN an BOYS, their rudimentary weapons pointed towards the ceili squeezed looking and sometimes avoiding each other's gaze exposing their fear and expectation.
I am not feeling my legs. It is like they are belonging to other
Outside, the SOUNDS of battle come from all directions. I an invisible looming threat heralded by a cacophony of hi pitched projectiles, ground shaking explosions, and CRIES the wounded.
BANG. Father looks out a small slit. He sees an NRC SOLDI FALL from a sniper hit. The soldiers move for cover, seemingly held at bay by the nearby shooter.
He looks back at all the faces in the room with him. Fear Another shot rings out, it is near. He looks up and reali the SNIPER is in their building.
(to his Father) Will they be killing us?
A MAN slaps his face, but he cannot see who it was.
Shut up!
If they are finding us...
Agu turns towards his father.
They will drive our body into the bush, just leaving us for animal to be eating.
(through his teeth) Shut up, I say. They will be finding us only if you keep talking.
And if they are rebel they will be cutting off our hand and holding them to be shaking each other, is that what you are wanting?
A STRING of BULLETS hits the concrete outside. Another EXPLOSION rocks the room. Agu's eyes fill with dread.
MAN #2                         MAN (CONT'D)
And if they are Army they       Shut up!    Shut up! will just be shooting us.
(whispering to Agu) Do not be listening to them, Agu. No matter what happens, this is how God tests us, we must be strong.
A SHRIEK startles them. Outside, SOLDIERS scream ORDERS t each other. They are VERY near.
(through his teeth) I am rather to be outside than to just be dying like animal inside!
Men murmur in agreement. Father sees a GOVERNMENT ARMY TA turn the corner.
We stay here, outside we die.
If we are running now, none of us will be having a chance.
Nobody says anything. Then... BANG. Another shot. Father looks and sees ONE MORE downed Government Soldier.
BOOM. B-BOOM. The tank fires into their building. Rocking structure and raining down water and chunks of cement. Al their ears are ringing.
We must go!
You are killing us all!
Agu is shaking.
If you are running fast, then the soldier won't be seeing you.
Agu looks between his Father and Big Brother. His eyes tearing, his stomach churning with fear and nausea.
Shut up, quiet, they will be hearing us!
Stay down!
They break the door open. Light, air, and sounds pour int the room. Everyone SIGHS.
BULLETS obliterate the three men by the door. GOVERNMENT SOLDIERS appear in the doorway, everyone throws their han up in surrender.

Agu, Big Brother, Father, Grandfather and several of the sit on the ground with their hands on their heads. THREE GOVERNMENT ARMY SOLDIERS hold them at gun point, prodding them, shoving their heads, toying with them and tying the up.
Agu notices that some of the NRC SOLDIERS ARE CHILDREN ju couple years older than himself.
A GOVERNMENT ARMY SERGEANT interrogates them.
Which faction are you fighting for?
We are not fighters. We are from this town. We were protecting the stores.
You are Native Defense Forces?
No. I am a Section Chief. We were tasked to stop looters.
(to his Corporal) Bring the woman.
You are calling us looters?
GOVERNMENT ARMY Soldiers exit buildings and connecting streets carrying looted goods. They dump them into their trucks.
The Corporal returns with the OLD WOMAN from his jeep.
Do you know these men?
The old woman looks at Father, then at Agu and his brothe She shakes her head.
I do not know them.
The MEN all YELL in protest. Agu looks angrily at the wretched woman.
This woman, everyone knows she is crazy. Just talk to her, Massah, you will see she is not right in the head.
They are not from here, they must be rebels.
The men protest. The Sergeant nods gravely.
We, the armed forces of the National Reformation Council, find you to be spies and sentence you to immediate and summary execution. (to the soldiers around
Waste them.
(looking at his boys) Run!
The men rise, those who haven't been tied yet put their h up and back away as the Government Army Soldiers shoot th to the ground, point blank.
Agu and Big Brother run.
Agu dodges around a corner as a bullet hits the wall besi him.

Safely around the corner, he stops and looks over for Big Brother who was just a second ago behind him. Agu looks d Big Brother is lying face down in a pool of blood. Agu reaches for his Big Brother as his body is pelted by bull
Reloading, they see Agu frozen in place. They aim to fire just as Agu regains his senses and runs.
Agu slams through the bush, branches scraping past him. H flip-flops slapping the red mud. Flinging it all over him
The sounds of WAR gone.
Agu wanders on his own. Lost, confused, angry, his emotio overwhelming him.
He cries drunkenly, walking deeper into the wilds.
Agu tries to sleep on a branch of a tree, he still cries mournful sob.
Agu again wanders the intermittent bush and woods.
He finds one rotten fruit hanging from a tree. Devours it
A small babbling creek. Agu drinks water. The sounds of animals in the forest suffocating.
Agu finds a hunting lodge of some kind. It has not been inhabited for some time.
He digs through what's left. Finds some grains of rice in bottom of a basket.
Agu has the grains of rice in an old pot with water. But cannot start a fire. He throws the pot in frustration, th immediately regrets it, running over to it to see if any the rice is left.
He cries again, more out of fatigue and hunger than sadne there is nothing else he knows to eat.
He tries eating grass.
Agu, stomach in pain, vomits.
Tired, hungry, thirsty, Agu walks aimlessly.
He sees a BOY, just a bit older than him, lithe and dark coal, in tribal dress, a thin stemmed flower head dress o his crown.
Agu, stops, unsure if he is real.
A forest spirit.
The boy runs away. Agu follows.
Agu crests the hill and into the valley below. He looks b the boy is gone. He runs deeper down a path leading into forest.
Suddenly the forest animals go unusually quiet.
Agu stops. Looks around. The forest is dark and unwelcome looms over him, seeming to grow taller in his mind.
He bends down into the tall grass, watching the forest se to move. Frightened, Agu lowers himself further, listenin watching.
SILENCE. The forest seems to move from inside. He freezes the hair tingling on the back of his neck, his mouth stil wrenched from crying.
FOOTSTEPS. GRASS RUSTLES. FOOTSTEPS LOUDER. Then, MACHINE FIRE zips over his head. The thick grass cut and pecked b bullets.
MEN rush and pounce past him but he cannot see them, he c only hear their desperation and equipment clanking.
Agu sees TWO PLF Rebels cresting the ridge line. POP POP, they drop.
He turns to see where the shot came from just in time to a SMALL BOY -- machete in hand, a shortened rifle strappe his back -- in mid-air jumping at him.
WHAM. The boy's foot lands with a thud on Agu's raised ar
Agu SCREAMS, sure he has been killed, tries crawling away turns and looks. The BOY whacks him with the broad side o the machete.
Agu SCREAMS and CRIES harder, curling like a beaten dog.
The boy hits him again and Agu relents. He sees a vision makes him sure he is dead.
This is what death is feeling like.
Out of the forest, a surreal spectacle: 50 NATIVE DEFENSE FORCE (NDF) SOLDIERS --- not GOVERNMENT or PLF REBEL --- emerge from the edge of the forest.
They look like they are wearing the costumes of some trib warrior ceremony. Their heads and bodies in elaborate gra wraps and crowns, amulets hang from their bodies.
ONE is stark NAKED except for lengths of belt-fed bullet chain wrapped around his body and leading into his GPMG.
They are ALL young, in their twenties, some boys in their teens and even younger.
Agu, hypnotized by their colorful, yet vigilant and poten presence, is in awe, until another BOOT pins him to the ground.
HANDS roughly turn him over. His shirt is yanked over his head and used to tie his arms behind his back. He is shov again, YELLED at, TAUNTED, until...
Make way!

SOMEONE is approaching from behind them, the NDF Soldiers finish tying Agu's arms, then step back in respect and wa a MAN pass, followed by an ENTOURAGE OF 10 more NDF Soldi his AIDE, CHIEF SECURITY OFFICER, BODY GUARDS, and CONTRO GUARD (a MAN who holds what equates to a Roman Eagle Staf adorned in tribal motifs) as well as a contingent of his SMALL BOY UNIT (SBU).
This MAN moves slowly, like someone who can afford to tak his time. His clothing tribal with a distinctive chief-li flare to it. There is no question, he is the boss, he is their COMMANDANT.

Commandant's CONVOY enters the complex through another checkpoint more heavily armed. Beyond it ARMED SECURITY PERSONNEL that look like our NDF FIGHTERS but with differ styles are scattered about the pathway leading to the interior of the complex which is filled with former combatants.
Confusion seems to reign as Agu strains to take in all th new sites.
The Charcoal NDF Soldier hands off Commandant to a DEPUTY for Supreme Commander Goodblood.
Commandant. Welcome.
Thank you Deputy.
Commandant seems to have little respect for this man, who leads them deeper into the complex, past a flurry of activity, aides with papers, armed guards, and other functionaries.
I have been asked to leave my men on the edge of town.
We apologize for the inconvenience. We do not want to alarm the population by the arrival of such a large force.
When can they enter? I have-
I do not know Goodblood's plan for you. I assure you, you will know A- S-A-P.
He motions for them to sit in an austere waiting room. A SINGLE ARMED GUARD in fatigues sleeps in the room. Deputy clears his throat.
You will wait here.
Commandant looks around the room, unimpressed.
You will bring something to drink for us. Water.
Certainly.
They sit. Collapsing with their field clothes into squeak and odd civilian spaces. Their weapons dangle on their si Two of the BODY GUARDS light a joint. Agu tugs on their shirts.
He notices the distant look on Commandant's face.
I am looking at him, and I am seeing he is not happy to be waiting.
Agu gets a hit of the joint. He too collapses against the floor, watching the clock, an analog mid-century clock wi hands that slowly rotate around its face.
And I am seeing these people entering with more than they are having when they are leaving and I am wondering why they are leaving their things behind and if I should be telling them.

We see CHINESE BUSINESS MEN enter the office, and then le and then Commandant readying himself as if it were their turn, but then the Deputy apologizes, and leads in a grou LEBANESE BUSINESS MEN who enter with brief cases and then exit without.
And with every person that is coming, and every person that is going, I am seeing anger on Commandant's face grow.
And as the clock moves faster, Commandant slams the arms his chair, BAM, waking the room, and the sleeping ARMED GUARD.
Just then the Deputy enters.
Supreme Commander is so very upset to keep you waiting. Please, follow me.
The men stand, stretching the stiff muscles. And go throu the doors into another, slightly more pleasant, waiting r
Please sit, I will be with you shortly.
What is this? This is just another room. Where is our water?
Agu raises his rifle at the Armed Guard.
Give us water! Give us water, now!
Commandant's Bodyguard's smile, as does Strika, the Armed Guard runs down the hall to oblige.
They sip water from plastic bags. An air conditioner hums Commandant sits deep in thought.
They are all sleeping.
Commandant.
They stir.
The Supreme Commander felt ill and has gone home for the evening.
The Deputy can see this will not satisfy Commandant, who looks like he could squeeze the life out of this function
But he invites you to his home first appointment in the morning.
Where are you putting us to be sleeping?
I hope this room, with the air conditioning, will be sufficient. Thank you, Gentlemen.
They walk down a pleasant hallway, as if they were on a museum tour, Strika and Agu are dazzled by the cleanlines it all.
Commandant, I trust you rested well. I would like you to know we also offered rations and water to the rest of your Battalion this morning.
Commandant walks past him.
Thank you, Deputy.
They spill out into a foyer flanked by a dining room and office with chairs arranged for long, circuitous conversations.
Commandant takes a seat, the rest of the entourage hold b uncomfortably, along the edge of the room.

The Deputy enters a door on the opposite side of the room where UHF radio chatter links Goodblood to his commanders fighters across the country. There, an elder statesman li intellectual appears in the doorway, DADA GOODBLOOD, foll by the deputy.

EVERYONE stands and salutes. Agu strains to finally see t man they have all spoken about. He wears a fine combinati of clothes, and looks smart, even in his morning slippers newspaper in hand, Deputy holds his coffee. He sits on th smaller chair, near to Commandant.
At ease Gentlemen. At ease...
Goodblood smiles warmly as he sits.
Commandant.
Supreme Commander, sah.
I must apologize for yesterday, so much busy-ness these days, it's worn me down.
Commandant doesn't hide his frustration.
I'm sorry you were feeling weak, sah.
I see your family has grown.
He looks at the entourage watching them, in particular th boys.
They will want to eat while we talk. Unless you are hungry, too?
Goodblood looks at Deputy, who quickly realizes he must u the men to the adjoining room that offers Commandant and Goodblood more privacy.
I am hungry. Two-I-C, bring me a plate.
Two-I-C starts to move-
Two-I-C, you stay. Deputy?
The Deputy nods dutifully.

In the dining room a table of European style food is quic sacked by the men. Strika and Agu stuff croissants into t pockets and sit on the floor, rolling slices of meat and stuffing them in their mouths.

Agu keeps one eye on the meeting, where the Commandant an Goodblood share weighted stares. Goodblood reading Commandant's emotional weariness, Commandant reading Goodblood's ill intentions. Two-I-C is paralyzed between them.
What is this, Chief? Why are you making me wait?
It is your duty.
Something has changed, what is it?
He sniffs out Goodblood.
We are not taking the Capital?
Protecting our people remains the priority. As you know, the world is becoming aware of this war, now. No one will escape judgment when it is over.
Chief, to protect our people, we have the force and the momentum, why stop, why wait?
It used to be survival of the strongest, the strong dominating by brute force, but now it is survival of the wittiest and the decisions we make have far deeper consequences.
Then what is your plan for my battalion? Are you not making me General?
I am not. I am giving your battalion to Two-I-C, Commandant. That is why I brought you here.
Two-I-C is overtly surprised, Commandant is able to conta his, only just.
And you, I will promote to Deputy Secretary of Defense. Effective immediately. I hope you will accept and act accordingly.
Thank you, suh!                  May we speak alone, chie
Two-I-C salutes, excitedly.
I promise to perform my duties to the fullest pot-
Two-I-C get out.
Two-I-C drops his salute and smile. He doesn't know wheth to stay or go. Goodblood releases him.

I want the ceremony of change over tomorrow, so that Two-I-C... I mean newly, Commandant in absence, may take the battalion back out for security details. As you know, and much thanks to you, we have the NRC on their heels. With support from the UN and ECOMOD, the battle now is for public image. Two-I-C and other commanders like him will provide that for us until the junta crumbles.
You are taking my battalion?
Commandant, your battalion is my battalion. One of hundreds across the nation. I will remind you that you are a soldier, you are subject to orders, you listen and obey orders.
Agu has never seen anyone speak to Commandant in this way
And for my services, Chief? I built this battalion. I am their father.
That honor remains yours.
And payment? What share of the resources will I have, for this honor?
If you are wanting to be a man of industry and resources, then find a job with a mining company. I am offering you something else entirely, an education.
Commandant steams, reading the room. SEVERAL of Goodblood SECURITY PERSONNEL quietly enter the edges of the room.
Do not forget, your most important duty is obedience. Your first duty is obedience...
your second duty, obedience. Your third, obedience. Everything is obedience. Without obedience you have nothing. Have you forgotten yourself?
Commandant adjusts his tone.
I have not Chief. I am not a politician, I am a soldier.
He looks at his men, motioning for them to get ready to g
I will have one last night with them.
Goodblood stands. The men stand and salute.
Move on!
Goodblood watches Commandant leave with calculation.
Commandant simmers.
Sah?!
Assemble the C/Os, take the troops and bivouac outside of town. I am taking Two-I-C with some of the boys to celebrate.
Yes, suh!
Where are we going?
You will see. You will like it.
Agu and Strika watch, anxiously wanting to join this adventure.
If you and Strika are my bodyguard, then if I am going, you are also going, you are hearing me?
Agu and Strika salute excitedly.
Commandant and his men stand outside a sealed door.
A dwarf like Old Woman SLIDES the window open.
A small room. A fluorescent light casting a blue glow ove everything. The men's faces shine with sweat. All of the windows and doorways have heavy black material blocking a light from escaping.
The men fill up the room. Agu looks up, he cannot believe what he sees.
Imagination TV.
On the screen is a bootleg Jimmy Cliff film.
A HEAVY WOMAN, THE MADAME, approaches them, her eyes shin with bright blue contacts, her body is curvaceous and she walks with a limp.
Enh, so you come?
Ma. Bring something that will satisfy my soldiers and my soldier!
The men laugh nervously, all still reeling. Commandant's in conflict with what he just received from Goodblood.
Bring beer! Bring soda! Bring it all!
The men laugh forcefully, glancing down the empty hall eagerly. Agu notices a GIRL, young and pretty, sleeping o bench at the exit to the room. The Madame shouts at her..
Get up you, can't you see we are having guest?
The young girl gets up slowly and goes to a cooler. She b over, all of the men lean to get a better view.
The beer is warm.
How is it warm?
No ice.
No ice!?
No light.
Bring the drink. We will be drinking it even if it is warm.
She sighs and fills a bucket with warm beer bottles.
Commandant. Permission to be dismissed. I want to be going to be checking on my men-
Commandant turns from smiling to deathly serious.
Negative. You'll be staying here so we can celebrate you. In fact, Mama, why don't you bring a special one for my Two-I-C, who will soon be the Co-mman-dan-tttt.
Who's your Commandant?
You, sir!
The Commandant's smile returns. He turns to the Madame.
But you have one special for Two-I- C?
The Madame laughs.
No problem. No problem.
The Commandant becomes serious again, his eyes seem to communicate something coded. The Madame's tone changes.
No problem.
Hey Mama, this one's fresh papaya.
The men laugh harder. She is annoyed, but not unaccustome Agu can tell now she is even younger than he thought she barely 14.
If it is woman you are wanting, leave this one. I am having plenty womens in the back if you are having plenty moneys to be giving me, for a special girl.
Don't you be worrying about money, ma. Bring me a good girl, you know my specifications.
Auntie! Auntie, bring us some chips!
The Madame turns towards him, sighing through her teeth.
This small thing borned yesterday trying to order things around, enh!
She goes and grabs a basket of crisps and places it in fr of Agu as FOUR WOMEN appear in the doorway.
We are having enough for you men, but there is no more girls for the little boys.
Agu looks up, angrily.
Commandant picks up a hesitant Two-I-C and pushes him out first, the rest of the men waste no time disappearing int the hall.
Within seconds, the room is empty, leaving Agu behind wit the girl. Strika, high and tired, lays on the floor to ta nap.
Agu sits with his head resting in his arms at the table. empty beer bottle laying in front of him. He watches the Jimmy Cliff movie.
Sweat beads on his nose as he eats a chip. The young woma collects the bottles on the table.
He studies her face, the pulsing of her blood in her neck the sweat on her brow and nose. He watches her butt move, breasts shake as she cleans the table off.
Slowly, he reaches out his hand to touch her, she turns a looks at him as if she would bite his arm off.
Frustrated and bored, he leaves the room.
Agu walks over to the shuttered windows of the "sex stall and watches various couples copulating. He reaches into h pants and touches himself when he hears a loud SHOT.
The doors to a room around the horseshoe shaped building swing open, as Two-I-C, half dressed and naked bursts out sliding down against the wall leaving a trail of blood.

The men drag Two-I-C down the hallway and back into the r with the TV, laying him out on the table. He bleeds from hole in his head, his face looks like all the pain in the world is coming through him.
Commandant enters last, only wearing a sheet.
What is happening? Huh? What happened?
(under his breath) You did this.
What happened to my man? Wh- What happened here?
They all look at the GIRL Two-I-C had been with, she look the Madame for succor. Two-I-C shakes on the table, his b going into shock.
I was just playing with his gun, and it just went off. I don't know what happened. I don't know- I'm sorry.
You did this. You did this.
Relax, relax, relax!
You did this! You did this!
The Commandant points, accusingly at the girl.
Agu grips his rifle, waiting for Commandant to give the order. GIRL                    COMMANDANT (CONT'D)
(crying)                     You thought you were shootin I didn't mean to.               me! GIRL                    COMMANDANT (CONT'D)
No, no, no!                     You thought it was me?
The girl cries. GIRL                     COMMANDANT (CONT'D)
I didn't mean to. I'm so         Are you trying to kill m sorry.                           and to kill my men? Huh!
The girl points her finger at the Madame.
She told me...
She told you? It was an accident!
Go!
On the Commandant's command, Agu and Strika turn on the g and Madame and shoot them to down.
Let's go! Let's go! Enh! Pick him up! I want you to take all their women! All of them!
Agu sits next to Two-I-C, who is wrapped in a blanket, shivering, his skin shines with a greenish pallor.
Agu squeezes a wet cloth over his forehead, dripping brow water.

His spirit is fighting to be let free from his body. (whispering to Two-I-C) It is hurting because you are thinking about it. If you are stopping to think about it, there is nothing to be feeling. The thinking is the hurting.
Outside and around the buildings, the rest of the NDF Battalion rests and waits for orders.

Two-I-C wheezes. Agu sits at one of the desks separating bullet from its shell, empties the gun powder onto a piec gum foil. Agu lights the powder in a POOF. He scrapes the white-grey residue into a line and sniffs it.
The moon is full and shines into the room. Finally, Two-I stops moaning. Agu turns and looks.
Approaching Two-I-C, thinking he is dead. Two-I-C's eyes open and he's trying to whisper something. Agu cannot hea it. He leans in closer. Two-I-C's breaths a death rattle.
You are just a boy.
Agu looks at his hand, clammy and yellow, fingers grippin his blanket.
Do you know you are just a boy?
Two-I-C begins to tremble, panic. Agu reaches for his han holds it.
Was this all for nothing?
He looks at Two-I-C, unsure why he is feeling sad for thi man at this moment.
It is like God is turning his gaze on Two-I-C.
Two-I-C exhales, the trembling ceases. He is dead. Agu, d by the fading light, walks to the balcony overlooking the town.
Agu? Is that you.
Agu can barely perceive Commandant sitting in the railing his skin reflecting the faint embers of a joint cupped in hands. Agu does not respond.
Agu. Come. Sit down with me.
Agu leans into the railing. Commandant rubs the back of h neck.
It is dangerous times now, Agu. Can't be trusting nobody. That is why it is always good to be sleeping with one eye open. And that is why I have you and Strika.
Tripod enters with RADIO OPERATOR.
Goodblood is asking for you.
Commandant waves him away. Tripod, aware things have chan waits an explanation.
Sometimes Agu, sometimes I am feeling sorry for you.
Agu cannot tell if he heard him say it or if he dreamed h said it.
Sometimes I am.
Two-I-C is dead.
Preacher SINGS over Two-I-C's body. They strip him of his "Two-I-C" jacket, his belt, boots, and anything else of u He is left with only his dirty socks and underwear.
It is taking Two-I-C all day to be dying, and then he is dying when the moon is full and the night is shining like silver.
You are my new Two-I-C.
Commandant places the jacket on Tripod, who proudly puts on over his bare chest.
The the only way not to be fighting anymore is to be dying.
This was not God's work. This was man's. The Supreme Commander was our friend. Now he is our enemy. But we are not fearing change... for we are strong!
Strong and proud!
That is why we should be taking our own territory and filling our own pockets. Move out.
The NDF Soldiers take stock in what they have, burn their vehicles and move out.
Fog swirls along the canopy of the jungle. Commandant's t has been reduced to a small lean to, separate from where everyone else sleeps under the trees.
Mother. If this war is ever ending I am thinking, I cannot be going back to doing child thing.
Everyone sleeps. Suddenly they are attacked from unseen forces. Bullets pound the ground around them, burying men dirt and tearing others up with shrapnel.
We are just wild animals now with no place to be going.
Agu and Strika hold each other while bullet shells pour o them. The battle is over as quickly as it began.
Commandant is frazzled. He picks up his hat, dusting it o while yelling for the men to fall back.
Preacher moves up and down the line, checking the men.
Tripod, Hope!

Agu looks down the line. They are both bleeding. Hope is dead. Tripod still breathes, but his body is leaking bloo from many wounds. He screams while staring wildly at ever looking down at him, breathing.
His eyes roll into the back of his head.
Bullet is just eating everything, leaf, tree, ground, person -- eating them -- just making person to bleed everywhere... so much blood.
They pick through the useful gear and begin to move out.
Preacher whispers a prayer to himself as Commandant pulls Tripod's Two-I-C jacket off and places it on Preacher, unceremoniously as the men move out.
Agu collapses with Strika at their next bivouac. The men nothing, they are all too exhausted.
GUN FIRE ECHOES in the distance. Everyone is silent looki at Commandant for guidance, waiting.
Commandant signals, move down the line..."move out."
Agu puts his pack on and starts to leave when he sees Str is immovable, lizard licking his chapped lips.
Strika? Strika! We are having to go or they will be leaving us.
Strika shakes his head.
Let's go.
Agu watches as the others disappear into the bush without them. He turns back to Strika.
Strika! We have to be going. Stand up and let's go!
Strika shakes his head, sadly.
What is wrong with you?
Agu goes to Strika.
What is wrong?
Strika looks at Agu, wheezing. He shows Agu a small shrap wound in his side.
Worried but with no other choice, Agu picks Strika up and throws him onto his back.
Agu notices a cricket on a leaf. He snatches it quickly, bites half of it, then gives the other half to Strika, wh lets it sit in his mouth with out swallowing.
I am wanting to say to Strika, I am tired too.
GUN FIRE ECHOES again in the distance. Quietly, they move again.
I am tired, and so the words are not coming out of my mouth.
Agu picks up Strika to carry him.
I will be an old man before this war is over...
Agu hears it and sits up quickly. It's the song his mothe used to sing to him in the kitchen hut.
Enh... Strika, a song. Music. Like my mother sings...
He looks around, trying to find its ephemeral source. But goes silent. He tries to see if Strika is listening, his resting on Agu's shoulder.
Strika?
He shakes Strika. But Strika doesn't respond.
Strika?
Realizing he is dead, Agu lays him down and cries.
Agu covers Strika with leaves.
Commandant looks at him, pitifully. Then leads the men on

text: Agu stands alone in knee deep water peeing into the same. notices a floating corpse next to where he is peeing, its BOOTS looking in decent condition.
He stops peeing and pries the boots off, falling back int the water.
When he gets up he notices the GIRL from the whorehouse, fully pregnant trying to climb out of the trench to escap
His first instinct is to grab his rifle and aim. She sees this, they lock eyes, but she tests him, stepping higher. lowers his aim.

She thanks him with her eyes, but doesn't make it more th 15 feet before SWOOFFF, a bullet from a SNIPER far off on other side of a BURNED FIELD drops her - the MEN the tren Agu is hiding in was built to hide from.
Agu, only briefly saddened by the quick end to the girl, back to prying off the dead man's boot.
The rain mists on Agu, newish boots hanging on his should from their laces. The MOTHER'S SONG sings again from some place off in the mist.
Mother, your song is making my body to move and I am not having to think anymore, not about Strika, not about this war, not about any of the thing that are jumping into my head.
He sits in a fox hole overlooking the burnt field. PREACH tries to take a pop shot at someone on the other side of field.
Ammo. Find me some fucking bullets to be shooting, Agu.
He is dead.
Who is dead?
Him.
Agu points to the man he pried the boots from. Bored, he to find ammo, digging through abandoned rifles and dead bodies.
I want to be going to that person who is singing and taking all of the sound so I can be keeping it in my pocket, to be having it for myself.
The trench is filled with more water. Agu walks through i towards the inner part of the NDF defenses, the water up his belly so he rests his rifle on his head.
I am wanting to lie down on the warm ground with my eye closed and the smell of mud in my nose, just like Strika.
Agu looks at his reflection in the water staring back at He moves, it moves. He walks, it follows. Around him, the have created smaller mini-indentations to protect themsel from the rain of shrapnel.
I am wanting to feel how the ground is wet all around my body so that if I am sweating, I am feeling like it is the ground sweating through me.
NDF Soldiers are like ghosts in the heavy mist. He cannot more than a couple feet in front of him at a time.

And I am wanting to stay in this same place forever, never moving for anything, just waiting waiting until dust is piling on me and grasses is covering me and insect is making their home in the space between my teeths.
He rounds an intersection in the trench with a wooden def protecting it from exposure, leading deeper into the wood
One onina tree will be growing from my body, so wide that its trunk is separating night and day and so tall that its top leaf is tickling the moon until the man living there is smiling.
Agu enters the gold mining area of their encampment. He s to put on his new boots while looking at the lackluster industry.
Commandant sits on a throne of earth, a purple rappa cove him from the rain like a tribal king. He stares at the sk joint hanging gingerly in his dirty fingers, ash floating the water all around him.
Commandant, suh. We are out of bullets.
Kai! This fog, Agu. It is our friend.
Agu nods, dutifully. Commandant relights the joint.
He motions for Agu to come over to him. Agu does, slowly, trudging through the shallower water. Commandant puts his on him, gently caressing his back.
It was not supposed to be the way it has come to be, Agu.
They are dead.
Who are dead?
Agu doesn't seem to know how to answer the question.
Everyone betrays you, eventually. But, I will always look out for you, Agu. I will look out for you because you are my son.
Out of the mist, Agu hears voices, restless voices.
And a son always protects his father.
Agu pulls away from Commandant and trudges towards the entrance to let Preacher through.
Out of my way.
Preacher emerges from the whiteness.
I am needing to be speaking with you Commandant.
What is all this noise?
Commandant shouts from his thrown.
We are leaving, sah.
Who and who is leaving?
Preacher pushes Agu aside, knocking him against the wall the trench.
Who is leaving?
Preacher blinks.
Two-I-C, go back to your post.
No, Sah. We are going.
You are the only one stupid standing in front of me.
I am going, sah! I have no bullets, I cannot be shooting our enemy with no bullets. There is no gold, no money, nothing to be buying more bullets. So I am going.
I am going too.
More voices call out from beyond the mist that they are leaving, farther and farther into the trenches, until the smallest voices are still yelling "me too!"
Commandant's eyes grow dark. Preacher subtly slides his h down his rifle, still hanging on his shoulder.
Electricity courses through Agu's temples, fear and confu cloud his face. More men move to support Preacher, and Ag sees this, knowing his bullets couldn't stop them all.

I see. I see you are a big man now, Two-I-C. And where will you be going? You will surrender to the other NDF? No. They will eat you. And to the ECOMOD? That would be wiser, but, then what? Jail? War crimes? If they let you go, you think you will ever have it as good as you have it right now in this mud? You think that you will be able to just do what you want in "peace"?
He paces along the trench, leaning into his men, centimet away from their noses.

You all will go back to your towns, but they will fear you. Your families will not associate with you. You will be nobodies, with your poor, uneducated minds. And you will sit all day, and you will watch the sun rise and set, waiting with thousands of others for some big man to come along and say "I have some job for you."
He looks around, gauging the comprehension of his men.
Orphans. You are all orphans like me. You think I will let you waste what little time you have left on this earth drinking black tea and playing draughts with your gun powder tea.
Commandant turns, looks at Agu, gripping his rifle.
Agu?
He walks straight towards Agu.
What are you thinking?
He grabs the rifle, kneels down, holding it against his h and closing his eyes.
You want to kill me?
Agu can't. Commandant is disappointed.
You want to surrender?
Agu nods.
Then surrender.
He turns to the rest of the men.

When you are poor and hungry with nothing to do with your nothing days, you will remember these days as your best. And know, one day I will call on you again. And you will come. Because you will remember this, and you will come running. Nobody has it better than us.
Preacher climbs out of the trench. The others move to fol Commandant turns to Agu, his rifle still raised.
Go!
Agu, in a column with the rest of the NDF Soldiers walks their arms and weapons raised flat in the air. The sun sh hot over their heads.

Sun, why are you even thinking to shine on this world. I am wanting to catch you in my hand, to be squeezing until the color is dripping out from you forever. That way everywhere it is always dark and nobody is ever having to see any of the terrible thing that is happening in this world.
In the distance, waiting UN forces guide them through the defensive position.

As they pass a line of former ECOMOD TROOPS now re-organi as UN forces, Agu notices the 2nd Lieutenant from his hom village, Alpha Town, the man he sold his imagination TV t but the man does not recognize Agu.
As Agu stares at him, the 2nd Lieutenant is forced to mak eye contact with him, but can't make out why this young fighter is staring at him.
In heaven, it is always morning.
A ceiling fan spins around in circles. Agu stares at it w laying in a clean bed of white sheets.
He is healthy. His skin fresh, his face filled in. His ey clear.
Outside, children scream -- with joy.
Agu sits up. Child-like drawings of war flutter on a desk under the ventilation of the fan. He steps out of bed and stares out the window.
Permanent wooden blinds split his view horizontally, but can see through them, at DOZENS of children running into turquoise waters of the ocean.
I am not knowing how long I am staying here, but I am staying here for a long time -- some week, some month -- I am not knowing. All I am knowing is how it is feeling here.
Agu stares at the other children at play.
He notices a miniature crab running sideways in the sand, making a tiny trail.
He looks back at the kids playing by the ocean.
A young WOMAN, AMY (20s) watches Agu. He doesn't join the other children, he stays separate.
Sometimes I am eating even if I am not hungrying too much because I am fearing that the food is finishing for the next day.
Agu dresses in new clothes, stares into a mirror at himse
I am liking the clothes is clean and dry and it is not having any hole from bullet or blood from the last person who is wearing it.
The children scream as FATHER FRIDAY, (50s) enters the compound in a Land Rover. They swarm him.
Father Friday sits in front of Agu.
Turn to God. Confession and Forgiveness and Resurrection, these are the things you need to know to bring the life back to your life...
He continues while Agu listens.

I am not knowing all what he is meaning. The only thing that is making sense to me is memory that I am having of another boy -- Strika - - sleeping next to me, so close because we are the only people protecting each other from all of the thing trying to kill us.
Agu and Strika holding on to each other.
Agu sits defensively in front of the Father.
The only thing I am knowing is the sound of people coughing and screaming, and the smell of going to toilet and dead body. And the feeling of the brown brown and djamba in my blood.
The same dorm room, several weeks earlier.
Agu sweats in bed, his body aching as the drugs and poiso leave his system. He shakes in bed.
The kids, including Agu, raid the kitchen threatening the COOKS, they lock them inside the kitchen and take over th school.

The CHILDREN -- months earlier when they first got to the shelter, are angry, confused, drugs still coursing throug their nervous systems -- burn items of furniture, beds, t legs, and throw them into the courtyard as the WORKERS tr calm them down.
Agu, though we cannot hear it, throws his fist in the air chanting.
